verb.description: (of a person) pull or drag with effort or force.
examples: he hauled his bike out of the shed

verb.description: (of a vehicle) pull (an attached trailer or load) behind it.
examples: the train was hauling a cargo of liquid chemicals

verb.description: (especially of a sailing ship) make an abrupt change of course.

noun.description: A quantity of something that was stolen or is possessed illegally.
examples: they escaped with a haul of antiques

phrases: Rather than hurrying to finish my last doodle, I carefully pack it away in my bag and, along with the rest of my gear, haul off to my locker.
he hauled off and smacked the kid
He growled and I didn't hesitate this time to just haul off and smack him.
Suddenly without warning, he hauls off and smacks her across the face.
seals haul out to bask in areas where they can see and smell approaching predators
origin: Mid 16th century (originally in the nautical sense trim sails for sailing closer to the wind): variant of hale.
